Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 7, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Almost 2000 years ago, the Roman philosopher Seneca peered 
at his book through a glass of water. Suddenly, the text below was transformed. The words magically became clear. But it wasn't until a millennium later
that that same principle would be used to create 
the earliest glasses. Today, glasses can help millions of people
with poor vision due to uncorrected refractive errors. The key to understanding what that means
lies with the term refraction, the ability of a transparent medium,
like glass, water, or the eye to change the direction
of light passing through it. The eye has two main refractive surfaces: the cornea and the lens. Ideally, these surfaces work together to refract light in a way that accurately
focuses light onto the retina, the layer of light-sensitive tissue
at the back of the eye that works with the brain
to give rise to vision. But many people develop refractive errors, either during childhood 
as their eyes are growing, or in later life as their eyes age. Imperfections in the cornea and lens cause refracted light to be focused
in front of or behind the retina, making images appear blurry. People with refractive errors
can still see color, movement, and light, but the details of what they're looking at
are out of focus. People experience refractive 
errors in different ways, owing to differences in their eyes. In some, light refracts too much, and in others, too little. Eyes with a focal point 
in front of the retina are called myopic, or short-sighted. They can see close objects clearly, but those far away are out of focus. But when the focus point 
is behind the retina, people are hyperopic,
or long-sighted. For them, objects close up
are unfocused, but distant objects are crystal clear. Finally, some people have a cornea
with a non-spherical shape that causes astigmatism, a form of out-of-focus vision
that makes all objects seem blurred, whether close or far. As we age, our eyes face new challenges. When we're young, the lens of the eye
is flexible and can change shape to bring
images into focus, something called accommodation. This keeps objects in focus when we
shift our gaze from far to near. But as we get older, the lens becomes
less flexible, and can't change shape when we want
to look at near objects. This is called presbyopia, and it affects adults starting
around the age of 40 years. Myopia, hyperopia, astigmatism, and presbyopia. Each of these is a refractive error. Nowadays we can fix them all with glasses
or contact lenses, which work by refocusing light
so it strikes the retina precisely. It's even possible to correct vision
with surgery using lasers that change the shape
of the cornea and alter its refractive properties. But glasses remain the most popular. By using carefully crafted lenses to steer light to exactly 
the right spot on the retina, a person's clear vision can be restored. We've come a long way 
since Seneca's discovery and the crude glasses of yesteryear. In 1727, a British optician named
Edward Scarlett developed the modern style of glasses which are kept in place with arms
which hook over each ear. Today's glasses take their inspiration
from that design, but they're also much more precise
and personal. Each pair is tailored for an individual
to bring out their unique powers of sight. So if you're one of the 500 million people
with a problem with close or far vision, or both, there's a pair of glasses out there
waiting to reveal a whole new world that's hiding in plain view.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: At what age do people typically start to need reading glasses (presbyopia)?
Options: A. 8 years, B. 21 years, C. 40 years, D. 70 years
Correct Option: C

Question 3: What are the two main refractive surfaces of the eye? Options: A. Cornea and retina, B. Lens and retina, C. Cornea and lens, D. Iris and pupil Correct Option: None

focuses light onto the retina, the layer of light-sensitive tissue
at the back of the eye that works with the brain
to give rise to vision. But many people develop refractive errors, either during childhood 
as their eyes are growing, or in later life as their eyes age. Imperfections in the cornea and lens cause refracted light to be focused
in front of or behind the retina, making images appear blurry. People with refractive errors
can still see color, movement, and light, but the details of what they're looking at
are out of focus. People experience refractive 
errors in different ways, owing to differences in their eyes. In some, light refracts too much, and in others, too little. Eyes with a focal point 
in front of the retina are called myopic, or short-sighted. They can see close objects clearly, but those far away are out of focus. But when the focus point 
is behind the retina, people are hyperopic,
or long-sighted. For them, objects close up
are unfocused, but distant objects are crystal clear. Finally, some people have a cornea
with a non-spherical shape that causes astigmatism, a form of out-of-focus vision
that makes all objects seem blurred, whether close or far. As we age, our eyes face new challenges. When we're young, the lens of the eye
is flexible and can change shape to bring
images into focus, something called accommodation. This keeps objects in focus when we
shift our gaze from far to near. But as we get older, the lens becomes
less flexible, and can't change shape when we want
to look at near objects. This is called presbyopia, and it affects adults starting
around the age of 40 years. Myopia, hyperopia, astigmatism, and presbyopia. Each of these is a refractive error. Nowadays we can fix them all with glasses
or contact lenses, which work by refocusing light
so it strikes the retina precisely. It's even possible to correct vision
with surgery using lasers that change the shape
of the cornea and alter its refractive properties. But glasses remain the most popular. By using carefully crafted lenses to steer light to exactly 
the right spot on the retina, a person's clear vision can be restored. We've come a long way 
since Seneca's discovery and the crude glasses of yesteryear. In 1727, a British optician named
Edward Scarlett developed the modern style of glasses which are kept in place with arms
which hook over each ear. Today's glasses take their inspiration
from that design, but they're also much more precise
and personal. Each pair is tailored for an individual
to bring out their unique powers of sight. So if you're one of the 500 million people
with a problem with close or far vision, or both, there's a pair of glasses out there
waiting to reveal a whole new world that's hiding in plain view.

**Transcript**:
Almost 2000 years ago, the Roman philosopher Seneca peered 
at his book through a glass of water. Suddenly, the text below was transformed. The words magically became clear. But it wasn't until a millennium later
that that same principle would be used to create 
the earliest glasses. Today, glasses can help millions of people
with poor vision due to uncorrected refractive errors. The key to understanding what that means
lies with the term refraction, the ability of a transparent medium,
like glass, water, or the eye to change the direction
of light passing through it. The eye has two main refractive surfaces: the cornea and the lens. Ideally, these surfaces work together to refract light in a way that accurately
focuses light onto the retina, the layer of light-sensitive tissue
at the back of the eye that works with the brain
to give rise to vision. But many people develop refractive errors, either during childhood 
as their eyes are growing, or in later life as their eyes age. Imperfections in the cornea and lens cause refracted light to be focused
in front of or behind the retina, making images appear blurry. People with refractive errors
can still see color, movement, and light, but the details of what they're looking at
are out of focus. People experience refractive 
errors in different ways, owing to differences in their eyes. In some, light refracts too much, and in others, too little. Eyes with a focal point 
in front of the retina are called myopic, or short-sighted. They can see close objects clearly, but those far away are out of focus. But when the focus point 
is behind the retina, people are hyperopic,
or long-sighted. For them, objects close up
are unfocused, but distant objects are crystal clear. Finally, some people have a cornea
with a non-spherical shape that causes astigmatism, a form of out-of-focus vision
that makes all objects seem blurred, whether close or far. As we age, our eyes face new challenges. When we're young, the lens of the eye
is flexible and can change shape to bring
images into focus, something called accommodation. This keeps objects in focus when we
shift our gaze from far to near. But as we get older, the lens becomes
less flexible, and can't change shape when we want
to look at near objects. This is called presbyopia, and it affects adults starting
around the age of 40 years. Myopia, hyperopia, astigmatism, and presbyopia. Each of these is a refractive error. Nowadays we can fix them all with glasses
or contact lenses, which work by refocusing light
so it strikes the retina precisely. It's even possible to correct vision
with surgery using lasers that change the shape
of the cornea and alter its refractive properties. But glasses remain the most popular. By using carefully crafted lenses to steer light to exactly 
the right spot on the retina, a person's clear vision can be restored. We've come a long way 
since Seneca's discovery and the crude glasses of yesteryear. In 1727, a British optician named
Edward Scarlett developed the modern style of glasses which are kept in place with arms
which hook over each ear. Today's glasses take their inspiration
from that design, but they're also much more precise
and personal. Each pair is tailored for an individual
to bring out their unique powers of sight. So if you're one of the 500 million people
with a problem with close or far vision, or both, there's a pair of glasses out there
waiting to reveal a whole new world that's hiding in plain view.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:

Options: A. Myopia, B. Hyperopia, C. Astigmatism, D. Presbyopia
Correct Option: A

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 9, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
How do schools of fish swim in harmony? And how do the tiny cells in your brain
give rise to the complex thoughts, memories, and consciousness that are you? Oddly enough, those questions have
the same general answer: emergence, or the spontaneous creation of
sophisticated behaviors and functions from large groups of simple elements. Like many animals, 
fish stick together in groups, but that's not just because
they enjoy each other's company. It's a matter of survival. Schools of fish exhibit 
complex swarming behaviors that help them evade hungry predators, while a lone fish is quickly singled out
as easy prey. So which brilliant fish leader
is the one in charge? Actually, no one is, and everyone is. So what does that mean? While the school of fish is elegantly
twisting, turning, and dodging sharks in what looks 
like deliberate coordination, each individual fish is actually
just following two basic rules that have nothing to do with the shark: one, stay close, but not too close
to your neighbor, and two, keep swimmming. As individuals, the fish are focused on
the minutiae of these local interactions, but if enough fish join the group,
something remarkable happens. The movement of individual fish 
is eclipsed by an entirely new entity: the school, which has its own
unique set of behaviors. The school isn't controlled
by any single fish. It simply emerges if you have enough fish
following the right set of local rules. It's like an accident that happens over
and over again, allowing fish all across the ocean
to reliably avoid predation. And it's not just fish. Emergence is a basic property of many
complex systems of interacting elements. For example, the specific way in which
millions of grains of sand collide and tumble over each other almost always produces the same
basic pattern of ripples. And when moisture freezes
in the atmosphere, the specific binding properties
of water molecules reliably produce radiating lattices
that form into beautiful snowflakes. What makes emergence so complex is that you can't understand it
by simply taking it apart, like the engine of a car. Taking things apart is a good first step
to understanding a complex system. But if you reduce a school of fish
to individuals, it loses the ability to evade predators, and there's nothing left to study. And if you reduce the brain 
to individual neurons, you're left with something that is
notoriously unreliable, and nothing like how we think and behave, at least most of the time. Regardless, whatever you're thinking about
right now isn't reliant on a single neuron
lodged in the corner of your brain. Rather, the mind emerges from
the collective activities of many, many neurons. There are billions of neurons 
in the human brain, and trillions of connections between
all those neurons. When you turn such a complicated
system like that on, it could behave in all sorts
of weird ways, but it doesn't. The neurons in our brain follow
simple rules, just like the fish, so that as a group, their activity
self-organizes into reliable patterns that let you do things 
like recognize faces, successfully repeat the same task
over and over again, and keep all those silly little habits
that everyone likes about you. So, what are the simple rules 
when it comes to the brain? The basic function of each neuron
in the brain is to either excite or inhibit
other neurons. If you connect a few neurons together
into a simple circuit, you can generate rhythmic patterns
of activity, feedback loops that ramp up
or shut down a signal, coincidence detectors, and disinhibition, where two inhibitory neurons
can actually activate another neuron by removing inhibitory brakes. As more and more neurons are connected, increasingly complex patterns 
of activity emerge from the network. Soon, so many neurons are interacting
in so many different ways at once that the system becomes chaotic. The trajectory of the network's activity
cannot be easily explained by the simple local circuits
described earlier. And yet, from this chaos,
patterns can emerge, and then emerge again and again
in a reproducible manner. At some point, these emergent
patterns of activity become sufficiently complex, and curious to begin studying
their own biological origins, not to mention emergence. And what we found in emergent phenomena
at vastly different scales is that same remarkable
characteristic as the fish displayed: That emergence doesn't require
someone or something to be in charge. If the right rules are in place, and some basic conditions are met, a complex system will fall into
the same habits over and over again, turning chaos into order. That's true in the molecular pandemonium
that lets your cells function, the tangled thicket of neurons
that produces your thoughts and identity, your network of friends and family, all the way up to the structures and
economies of our cities across the planet.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What two simple rules do individual fish follow that allows them aggregate into schools (pick two of the below)? A. keep swimming B. do whatever you want C. stay close to your neighbor D. move in the opposite direction of predators
Options: A. A & B, B. A & C, C. A & D, D. B & C, E. B & D
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is emergence in the context of complex systems? Options: A. The creation of complex behaviors and functions through deliberate coordination, B. The spontaneous creation of sophisticated behaviors and functions from large groups of simple elements, C. The breakdown of complex systems into individual components, D. The study of individual elements in a complex system Correct Option: None
Question 2: Why do fish swim in schools? Options: A. Because they enjoy each other's company, B. To evade hungry predators, C. To find food more efficiently, D. To migrate to warmer waters Correct Option: None
Question 3: What are the two basic rules that individual fish follow in a school? Options: A. Stay close to the shark and keep swimming, B. Stay close, but not too close to your neighbor, and keep swimming, C. Follow the leader and stay alert, D. Swim in a random pattern and avoid collisions Correct Option: None
Question 4: What happens when enough fish join a group following the right set of local rules? Options: A. The movement of individual fish becomes more chaotic, B. The school becomes controlled by a single fish, C. The movement of individual fish is eclipsed by an entirely new entity: the school, D. The fish start to swim in a random pattern Correct Option: None
Question 5: What is an example of emergence in a non-living system? Options: A. The formation of snowflakes, B. The movement of a school of fish, C. The growth of a city's economy, D. The behavior of a single neuron Correct Option: None
Question 6: Why can't emergence be understood by simply taking it apart? Options: A. Because it is a complex system with many interacting elements, B. Because it is a simple system with few interacting elements, C. Because it is a living system, D. Because it is a non-living system Correct Option: None
Question 7: What is the basic function of each neuron in the brain? Options: A. To control the movement of the body, B. To recognize faces and patterns, C. To either excite or inhibit other neurons, D. To store memories and information Correct Option: None
Question 8: What happens when more and more neurons are connected in the brain? Options: A. The system becomes less complex and more predictable, B. The system becomes more complex and chaotic, C. The system remains the same, D. The system becomes less chaotic and more predictable Correct Option: None
Question 9: What is a characteristic of emergent phenomena at vastly different scales? Options: A. That emergence requires someone or something to be in charge, B. That emergence doesn't require someone or something to be in charge, C. That emergence is only found in living systems, D. That emergence is only found in non-living systems Correct Option: None
Question 10: What is an example of emergence in a social system? Options: A. The behavior of a single neuron, B. The movement of a school of fish, C. The growth of a city's economy, D. The network of friends and family Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 3: What are the two basic rules that individual fish follow in a school? 

This question matches the ground truth MCQ in terms of question intent, options, and content. Both questions ask about the simple rules that individual fish follow to aggregate into schools, and the correct answer in Question 3 (Option B: Stay close, but not too close to your neighbor, and keep swimming) matches the correct answer in the ground truth MCQ (Option B: A & C, where A is "keep swimming" and C is "stay close to your neighbor").

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 3.

Question: What are the two basic ways in which neurons interact with each other (pick two)? A. excitation B. inhibition C. dis-inhibition D. central pattern generator
Options: A. C & D, B. B & C, C. A & B, D. B & D
Correct Option: C

Question 9: What is a characteristic of emergent phenomena at vastly different scales? Options: A. That emergence requires someone or something to be in charge, B. That emergence doesn't require someone or something to be in charge, C. That emergence is only found in living systems, D. That emergence is only found in non-living systems Correct Option: None
Question 10: What is an example of emergence in a social system? Options: A. The behavior of a single neuron, B. The movement of a school of fish, C. The growth of a city's economy, D. The network of friends and family Correct Option: None

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 9, Question 5
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
How do schools of fish swim in harmony? And how do the tiny cells in your brain
give rise to the complex thoughts, memories, and consciousness that are you? Oddly enough, those questions have
the same general answer: emergence, or the spontaneous creation of
sophisticated behaviors and functions from large groups of simple elements. Like many animals, 
fish stick together in groups, but that's not just because
they enjoy each other's company. It's a matter of survival. Schools of fish exhibit 
complex swarming behaviors that help them evade hungry predators, while a lone fish is quickly singled out
as easy prey. So which brilliant fish leader
is the one in charge? Actually, no one is, and everyone is. So what does that mean? While the school of fish is elegantly
twisting, turning, and dodging sharks in what looks 
like deliberate coordination, each individual fish is actually
just following two basic rules that have nothing to do with the shark: one, stay close, but not too close
to your neighbor, and two, keep swimmming. As individuals, the fish are focused on
the minutiae of these local interactions, but if enough fish join the group,
something remarkable happens. The movement of individual fish 
is eclipsed by an entirely new entity: the school, which has its own
unique set of behaviors. The school isn't controlled
by any single fish. It simply emerges if you have enough fish
following the right set of local rules. It's like an accident that happens over
and over again, allowing fish all across the ocean
to reliably avoid predation. And it's not just fish. Emergence is a basic property of many
complex systems of interacting elements. For example, the specific way in which
millions of grains of sand collide and tumble over each other almost always produces the same
basic pattern of ripples. And when moisture freezes
in the atmosphere, the specific binding properties
of water molecules reliably produce radiating lattices
that form into beautiful snowflakes. What makes emergence so complex is that you can't understand it
by simply taking it apart, like the engine of a car. Taking things apart is a good first step
to understanding a complex system. But if you reduce a school of fish
to individuals, it loses the ability to evade predators, and there's nothing left to study. And if you reduce the brain 
to individual neurons, you're left with something that is
notoriously unreliable, and nothing like how we think and behave, at least most of the time. Regardless, whatever you're thinking about
right now isn't reliant on a single neuron
lodged in the corner of your brain. Rather, the mind emerges from
the collective activities of many, many neurons. There are billions of neurons 
in the human brain, and trillions of connections between
all those neurons. When you turn such a complicated
system like that on, it could behave in all sorts
of weird ways, but it doesn't. The neurons in our brain follow
simple rules, just like the fish, so that as a group, their activity
self-organizes into reliable patterns that let you do things 
like recognize faces, successfully repeat the same task
over and over again, and keep all those silly little habits
that everyone likes about you. So, what are the simple rules 
when it comes to the brain? The basic function of each neuron
in the brain is to either excite or inhibit
other neurons. If you connect a few neurons together
into a simple circuit, you can generate rhythmic patterns
of activity, feedback loops that ramp up
or shut down a signal, coincidence detectors, and disinhibition, where two inhibitory neurons
can actually activate another neuron by removing inhibitory brakes. As more and more neurons are connected, increasingly complex patterns 
of activity emerge from the network. Soon, so many neurons are interacting
in so many different ways at once that the system becomes chaotic. The trajectory of the network's activity
cannot be easily explained by the simple local circuits
described earlier. And yet, from this chaos,
patterns can emerge, and then emerge again and again
in a reproducible manner. At some point, these emergent
patterns of activity become sufficiently complex, and curious to begin studying
their own biological origins, not to mention emergence. And what we found in emergent phenomena
at vastly different scales is that same remarkable
characteristic as the fish displayed: That emergence doesn't require
someone or something to be in charge. If the right rules are in place, and some basic conditions are met, a complex system will fall into
the same habits over and over again, turning chaos into order. That's true in the molecular pandemonium
that lets your cells function, the tangled thicket of neurons
that produces your thoughts and identity, your network of friends and family, all the way up to the structures and
economies of our cities across the planet.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What is NOT a good example of a system that might exhibit emergent behaviors?
Options: A. Sand structures formed in a windy environment, B. A school of fish, C. A single wandering orangutan, D. A colony of ants
Correct Option: C

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 10, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Your rich, eccentric uncle 
just passed away, and you and your 99 nasty relatives have
been invited to the reading of his will. He wanted to leave 
all of his money to you, but he knew that if he did,
your relatives would pester you forever. So he is banking on the fact that he taught you everything 
you need to know about riddles. Your uncle left the following 
note in his will: "I have created a puzzle. If all 100 of you answer it together,
you will share the money evenly. However, if you are the first to find
the pattern and solve the problem without going through all of the leg work, you will get the entire inheritance 
all to yourself. Good luck." The lawyer takes you and your 99 relatives
to a secret room in the mansion that contains 100 lockers, each hiding a single word. He explains: Every relative is assigned a number
from 1 to 100. Heir 1 will open every locker. Heir 2 will then 
close every second locker. Heir 3 will change the status
of every third locker, specifically if it's open, 
she'll close it, but if it's closed, she'll open it. This pattern will continue until
all 100 of you have gone. The words in the lockers that remain
open at the end will help you crack the code for the safe. Before cousin Thaddeus can even start
down the line, you step forward and tell the lawyer
you know which lockers will remain open. But how? Pause the video now if you want
to figure it out for yourself! Answer in: 3 Answer in: 2 Answer in: 1 The key is realizing that the number
of times a locker is touched is the same as the number of factors
in the locker number. For example, in locker #6, Person 1 will open it, Person 2 will close it, Person 3 will open it, and Person 6 will close it. The numbers 1, 2, 3, and 6 
are the factors of 6. So when a locker has an even number
of factors it will remain closed, and when it has an odd number of factors, it will remain open. Most of the lockers 
have an even number of factors, which makes sense because factors
naturally pair up. In fact, the only lockers that have
an odd number of factors are perfect squares because those have one factor that when
multiplied by itself equals the number. For Locker 9, 1 will open it, 3 will close, and 9 will open it. 3 x 3 = 9, but the 3 can only be counted once. Therefore, every locker that is 
a perfect square will remain open. You know that these ten lockers 
are the solution, so you open them immediately
and read the words inside: "The code is the first five lockers
touched only twice." You realize that the only lockers 
touched twice have to be prime numbers since each only has two factors: 1 and itself. So the code is 2-3-5-7-11. The lawyer brings you to the safe, and you claim your inheritance. Too bad your relatives were always
too busy being nasty to each other to pay attention 
to your eccentric uncle's riddles.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What is the first locker to remain open?
Options: A. 1, B. 2, C. 10, D. 100
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the condition for all 100 relatives to share the inheritance evenly? Options: A. If one of them solves the puzzle first, B. If all of them answer the puzzle together, C. If they work in teams to solve the puzzle, D. If they draw a lottery to decide who gets the inheritance Correct Option: None
Question 2: What is the pattern that Heir 3 follows when changing the status of the lockers? Options: A. She opens every third locker, B. She closes every third locker, C. If a locker is open, she closes it; if it's closed, she opens it, D. She leaves every third locker unchanged Correct Option: None
Question 3: What is the key to realizing which lockers will remain open at the end? Options: A. The number of times a locker is touched is the same as the number of factors in the locker number, B. The number of times a locker is touched is the same as the number of relatives, C. The number of times a locker is touched is random, D. The number of times a locker is touched is the same as the number of lockers Correct Option: None
Question 4: What type of numbers have an odd number of factors, resulting in the corresponding lockers remaining open? Options: A. Prime numbers, B. Perfect squares, C. Even numbers, D. Odd numbers Correct Option: None
Question 5: Why do most lockers have an even number of factors? Options: A. Because factors naturally pair up, B. Because factors are random, C. Because factors are always odd, D. Because factors are always even Correct Option: None
Question 6: What is the code to the safe, as revealed by the words in the open lockers? Options: A. The first five lockers touched only once, B. The first five lockers touched only twice, C. The last five lockers touched only once, D. The last five lockers touched only twice Correct Option: None
Question 7: What type of numbers are the lockers that are touched only twice, revealing the code to the safe? Options: A. Perfect squares, B. Prime numbers, C. Even numbers, D. Odd numbers Correct Option: None
Question 8: How many factors do prime numbers have, resulting in the corresponding lockers being touched only twice? Options: A. 1, B. 2, C. 3, D. 4 Correct Option: None
Question 9: What is the sequence of numbers that forms the code to the safe? Options: A. 1-2-3-4-5, B. 2-3-5-7-11, C. 3-5-7-9-11, D. 1-3-5-7-9 Correct Option: None
Question 10: What is the outcome for the relatives if one of them solves the puzzle first? Options: A. They will share the inheritance evenly, B. The first one to solve the puzzle will get the entire inheritance, C. They will have to work together to solve another puzzle, D. They will have to draw a lottery to decide who gets the inheritance Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
None of the generated MCQs directly match the ground truth MCQ. However, based on the question intent, options, and content, the most similar generated MCQ would be one that deals with the properties of perfect squares or the pattern of opening and closing lockers.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 10, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Your rich, eccentric uncle 
just passed away, and you and your 99 nasty relatives have
been invited to the reading of his will. He wanted to leave 
all of his money to you, but he knew that if he did,
your relatives would pester you forever. So he is banking on the fact that he taught you everything 
you need to know about riddles. Your uncle left the following 
note in his will: "I have created a puzzle. If all 100 of you answer it together,
you will share the money evenly. However, if you are the first to find
the pattern and solve the problem without going through all of the leg work, you will get the entire inheritance 
all to yourself. Good luck." The lawyer takes you and your 99 relatives
to a secret room in the mansion that contains 100 lockers, each hiding a single word. He explains: Every relative is assigned a number
from 1 to 100. Heir 1 will open every locker. Heir 2 will then 
close every second locker. Heir 3 will change the status
of every third locker, specifically if it's open, 
she'll close it, but if it's closed, she'll open it. This pattern will continue until
all 100 of you have gone. The words in the lockers that remain
open at the end will help you crack the code for the safe. Before cousin Thaddeus can even start
down the line, you step forward and tell the lawyer
you know which lockers will remain open. But how? Pause the video now if you want
to figure it out for yourself! Answer in: 3 Answer in: 2 Answer in: 1 The key is realizing that the number
of times a locker is touched is the same as the number of factors
in the locker number. For example, in locker #6, Person 1 will open it, Person 2 will close it, Person 3 will open it, and Person 6 will close it. The numbers 1, 2, 3, and 6 
are the factors of 6. So when a locker has an even number
of factors it will remain closed, and when it has an odd number of factors, it will remain open. Most of the lockers 
have an even number of factors, which makes sense because factors
naturally pair up. In fact, the only lockers that have
an odd number of factors are perfect squares because those have one factor that when
multiplied by itself equals the number. For Locker 9, 1 will open it, 3 will close, and 9 will open it. 3 x 3 = 9, but the 3 can only be counted once. Therefore, every locker that is 
a perfect square will remain open. You know that these ten lockers 
are the solution, so you open them immediately
and read the words inside: "The code is the first five lockers
touched only twice." You realize that the only lockers 
touched twice have to be prime numbers since each only has two factors: 1 and itself. So the code is 2-3-5-7-11. The lawyer brings you to the safe, and you claim your inheritance. Too bad your relatives were always
too busy being nasty to each other to pay attention 
to your eccentric uncle's riddles.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: How many factors does the number 16 have, including 1 and itself?
Options: A. 2, B. 4, C. 5, D. 6
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the condition for all 100 relatives to share the inheritance evenly? Options: A. If one of them solves the puzzle first, B. If all of them answer the puzzle together, C. If they work in teams to solve the puzzle, D. If they draw a lottery to decide who gets the inheritance Correct Option: None
Question 2: What is the pattern that Heir 3 follows when changing the status of the lockers? Options: A. She opens every third locker, B. She closes every third locker, C. If a locker is open, she closes it; if it's closed, she opens it, D. She leaves every third locker unchanged Correct Option: None
Question 3: What is the key to realizing which lockers will remain open at the end? Options: A. The number of times a locker is touched is the same as the number of factors in the locker number, B. The number of times a locker is touched is the same as the number of relatives, C. The number of times a locker is touched is random, D. The number of times a locker is touched is the same as the number of lockers Correct Option: None
Question 4: What type of numbers have an odd number of factors, resulting in the corresponding lockers remaining open? Options: A. Prime numbers, B. Perfect squares, C. Even numbers, D. Odd numbers Correct Option: None
Question 5: Why do most lockers have an even number of factors? Options: A. Because factors naturally pair up, B. Because factors are random, C. Because factors are always odd, D. Because factors are always even Correct Option: None
Question 6: What is the code to the safe, as revealed by the words in the open lockers? Options: A. The first five lockers touched only once, B. The first five lockers touched only twice, C. The last five lockers touched only once, D. The last five lockers touched only twice Correct Option: None
Question 7: What type of numbers are the lockers that are touched only twice, revealing the code to the safe? Options: A. Perfect squares, B. Prime numbers, C. Even numbers, D. Odd numbers Correct Option: None
Question 8: How many factors do prime numbers have, resulting in the corresponding lockers being touched only twice? Options: A. 1, B. 2, C. 3, D. 4 Correct Option: None
Question 9: What is the sequence of numbers that forms the code to the safe? Options: A. 1-2-3-4-5, B. 2-3-5-7-11, C. 3-5-7-9-11, D. 1-3-5-7-9 Correct Option: None
Question 10: What is the outcome for the relatives if one of them solves the puzzle first? Options: A. They will share the inheritance evenly, B. The first one to solve the puzzle will get the entire inheritance, C. They will have to work together to solve another puzzle, D. They will have to draw a lottery to decide who gets the inheritance Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
None of the generated MCQs directly match the ground truth MCQ in terms of question content, options, and intent. However, based on the topic of factors and the relationship to the transcript, I would identify Question 5 as the most similar generated MCQ, although it does not directly ask about the number of factors for a specific number.

A more relevant question would be one that directly asks about the number of factors for a given number, such as 16. Unfortunately, none of the generated MCQs match this criteria.

If I had to choose one, I would say Question 5 is the closest match, but it's not a direct match.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 10, Question 5
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Your rich, eccentric uncle 
just passed away, and you and your 99 nasty relatives have
been invited to the reading of his will. He wanted to leave 
all of his money to you, but he knew that if he did,
your relatives would pester you forever. So he is banking on the fact that he taught you everything 
you need to know about riddles. Your uncle left the following 
note in his will: "I have created a puzzle. If all 100 of you answer it together,
you will share the money evenly. However, if you are the first to find
the pattern and solve the problem without going through all of the leg work, you will get the entire inheritance 
all to yourself. Good luck." The lawyer takes you and your 99 relatives
to a secret room in the mansion that contains 100 lockers, each hiding a single word. He explains: Every relative is assigned a number
from 1 to 100. Heir 1 will open every locker. Heir 2 will then 
close every second locker. Heir 3 will change the status
of every third locker, specifically if it's open, 
she'll close it, but if it's closed, she'll open it. This pattern will continue until
all 100 of you have gone. The words in the lockers that remain
open at the end will help you crack the code for the safe. Before cousin Thaddeus can even start
down the line, you step forward and tell the lawyer
you know which lockers will remain open. But how? Pause the video now if you want
to figure it out for yourself! Answer in: 3 Answer in: 2 Answer in: 1 The key is realizing that the number
of times a locker is touched is the same as the number of factors
in the locker number. For example, in locker #6, Person 1 will open it, Person 2 will close it, Person 3 will open it, and Person 6 will close it. The numbers 1, 2, 3, and 6 
are the factors of 6. So when a locker has an even number
of factors it will remain closed, and when it has an odd number of factors, it will remain open. Most of the lockers 
have an even number of factors, which makes sense because factors
naturally pair up. In fact, the only lockers that have
an odd number of factors are perfect squares because those have one factor that when
multiplied by itself equals the number. For Locker 9, 1 will open it, 3 will close, and 9 will open it. 3 x 3 = 9, but the 3 can only be counted once. Therefore, every locker that is 
a perfect square will remain open. You know that these ten lockers 
are the solution, so you open them immediately
and read the words inside: "The code is the first five lockers
touched only twice." You realize that the only lockers 
touched twice have to be prime numbers since each only has two factors: 1 and itself. So the code is 2-3-5-7-11. The lawyer brings you to the safe, and you claim your inheritance. Too bad your relatives were always
too busy being nasty to each other to pay attention 
to your eccentric uncle's riddles.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What is the pattern of the numbers of the lockers that remain open?
Options: A. They are odd numbers, B. They are even numbers, C. They are prime numbers, D. They are perfect squares
Correct Option: D

The number of times a locker is touched is the same as the number of lockers Correct Option: None

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 11, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Many of the inanimate objects around you
probably seem perfectly still. But look deep into the atomic structure
of any of them, and you'll see a world in constant flux. Stretching, contracting, springing, jittering, drifting atoms everywhere. And though that movement may seem chaotic,
it's not random. Atoms that are bonded together, and that describes almost all substances, move according to a set of principles. For example, take molecules,
atoms held together by covalent bonds. There are three basic ways 
molecules can move: rotation, translation, and vibration. Rotation and translation 
move a molecule in space while its atoms stay 
the same distance apart. Vibration, on the other hand, 
changes those distances, actually altering the molecule's shape. For any molecule, you can count up
the number of different ways it can move. That corresponds to 
its degrees of freedom, which in the context of mechanics basically means the number of variables
we need to take into account to understand the full system. Three-dimensional space is defined by
x, y, and z axes. Translation allows the molecule to move
in the direction of any of them. That's three degrees of freedom. It can also rotate around 
any of these three axes. That's three more, unless it's a linear molecule, 
like carbon dioxide. There, one of the rotations just spins
the molecule around its own axis, which doesn't count because it doesn't
change the position of the atoms. Vibration is where it gets a bit tricky. Let's take a simple molecule,
like hydrogen. The length of the bond that holds the two
atoms together is constantly changing as if the atoms were connected 
by a spring. That change in distance is tiny,
less than a billionth of a meter. The more atoms and bonds a molecule has,
the more vibrational modes. For example, a water molecule 
has three atoms: one oxygen and two hydrogens,
and two bonds. That gives it three modes of vibration: symmetric stretching, asymmetric stretching, and bending. More complicated molecules have even
fancier vibrational modes, like rocking, wagging, and twisting. If you know how many atoms a molecule has,
you can count its vibrational modes. Start with the total degrees of freedom, which is three times the number
of atoms in the molecule. That's because each atom can move
in three different directions. Three of the total correspond 
to translation when all the atoms 
are going in the same direction. And three, or two for linear molecules,
correspond to rotations. All the rest, 3N-6
or 3N-5 for linear molecules, are vibrations. So what's causing all this motion? Molecules move because they absorb
energy from their surroundings, mainly in the form of heat
or electromagnetic radiation. When this energy gets transferred
to the molecules, they vibrate, rotate, or translate faster. Faster motion increases the kinetic energy
of the molecules and atoms. We define this as an increase 
in temperature and thermal energy. This is the phenomenon your microwave oven
uses to heat your food. The oven emits microwave radiation,
which is absorbed by the molecules, especially those of water. They move around faster and faster, bumping into each other and increasing
the food's temperature and thermal energy. The greenhouse effect is another example. Some of the solar radiation 
that hits the Earth's surface is reflected back to the atmosphere. Greenhouse gases, like water vapor
and carbon dioxide absorb this radiation and speed up. These hotter, faster-moving molecules
emit infrared radiation in all directions, including back to Earth, warming it. Does all this molecular motion ever stop? You might think that would happen
at absolute zero, the coldest possible temperature. No one's ever managed to cool
anything down that much, but even if we could, molecules would still move due to
a quantum mechanical principle called zero-point energy. In other words, everything has been moving
since the universe's very first moments, and will keep going long, 
long after we're gone.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: How many rotational ‘degrees of freedom’ does a non-linear molecule have?
Options: A. 3N, B. 3N-5, C. 6, D. 3N-6
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the primary cause of the constant motion of molecules? Options: A. Absorption of energy from their surroundings, B. Random chaotic movement, C. Gravitational forces, D. Electromagnetic fields Correct Option: None
Question 2: What are the three basic ways molecules can move? Options: A. Rotation, translation, and vibration, B. Rotation, translation, and oscillation, C. Vibration, oscillation, and rotation, D. Translation, vibration, and reflection Correct Option: None
Question 3: What is the term used to describe the number of variables needed to understand the full system of a molecule's motion? Options: A. Degrees of freedom, B. Molecular motion, C. Kinetic energy, D. Thermal energy Correct Option: None
Question 4: How many degrees of freedom does a molecule have for translation in three-dimensional space? Options: A. 1, B. 2, C. 3, D. 4 Correct Option: None
Question 5: What is the difference in the number of rotational degrees of freedom between a linear molecule and a non-linear molecule? Options: A. 1, B. 2, C. 3, D. 0 Correct Option: None
Question 6: What is the term used to describe the tiny change in distance between atoms in a molecule due to vibration? Options: A. Symmetric stretching, B. Asymmetric stretching, C. Bending, D. None of the above Correct Option: None
Question 7: How can you calculate the number of vibrational modes of a molecule? Options: A. 3N-6 (or 3N-5 for linear molecules), B. 3N-3 (or 3N-2 for linear molecules), C. 3N-2 (or 3N-1 for linear molecules), D. 3N-1 (or 3N for linear molecules) Correct Option: None
Question 8: What is the primary cause of the increase in temperature and thermal energy of a substance? Options: A. Absorption of energy from surroundings, B. Emission of energy to surroundings, C. Increase in kinetic energy, D. Decrease in kinetic energy Correct Option: None
Question 9: What is the phenomenon used by microwave ovens to heat food? Options: A. Conduction, B. Convection, C. Radiation, D. None of the above Correct Option: None
Question 10: Why do molecules continue to move even at absolute zero? Options: A. Due to residual heat energy, B. Due to external forces, C. Due to zero-point energy, D. Due to random chaotic movement Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
None of the generated MCQs directly match the ground truth MCQ. However, based on the content and intent, the most similar generated MCQ is Question 4, which deals with the degrees of freedom for translation in three-dimensional space.

However, a more relevant question is Question 5, which deals with the difference in rotational degrees of freedom between linear and non-linear molecules.

But since none of the generated MCQs directly ask about the rotational degrees of freedom of a non-linear molecule, the best match would be Question 5, assuming that if we knew the difference between linear and non-linear, and we knew that linear had 2 rotational degrees of freedom, we could infer the degrees of freedom for the non-linear.

So the index of the most similar generated MCQ is 5.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 11, Question 2

long after we're gone.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:

Options: A. Vibration, B. Rotation, C. Translation, D. Infatuation
Correct Option: B

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 11, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. **Transcript**:
Many of the inanimate objects around you
probably seem perfectly still. But look deep into the atomic structure
of any of them, and you'll see a world in constant flux. Stretching, contracting, springing, jittering, drifting atoms everywhere. And though that movement may seem chaotic,

atoms held together by covalent bonds. There are three basic ways

the same distance apart. Vibration, on the other hand,

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Carbon dioxide has ____ rotational and ____ translational modes of motion.
Options: A. 4; 3, B. 3; 2, C. 2; 3, D. 3; 3
Correct Option: C

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 11, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Many of the inanimate objects around you
probably seem perfectly still. But look deep into the atomic structure
of any of them, and you'll see a world in constant flux. Stretching, contracting, springing, jittering, drifting atoms everywhere. And though that movement may seem chaotic,
it's not random. Atoms that are bonded together, and that describes almost all substances, move according to a set of principles. For example, take molecules,
atoms held together by covalent bonds. There are three basic ways 
molecules can move: rotation, translation, and vibration. Rotation and translation 
move a molecule in space while its atoms stay 
the same distance apart. Vibration, on the other hand, 
changes those distances, actually altering the molecule's shape. For any molecule, you can count up
the number of different ways it can move. That corresponds to 
its degrees of freedom, which in the context of mechanics basically means the number of variables
we need to take into account to understand the full system. Three-dimensional space is defined by
x, y, and z axes. Translation allows the molecule to move
in the direction of any of them. That's three degrees of freedom. It can also rotate around 
any of these three axes. That's three more, unless it's a linear molecule, 
like carbon dioxide. There, one of the rotations just spins
the molecule around its own axis, which doesn't count because it doesn't
change the position of the atoms. Vibration is where it gets a bit tricky. Let's take a simple molecule,
like hydrogen. The length of the bond that holds the two
atoms together is constantly changing as if the atoms were connected 
by a spring. That change in distance is tiny,
less than a billionth of a meter. The more atoms and bonds a molecule has,
the more vibrational modes. For example, a water molecule 
has three atoms: one oxygen and two hydrogens,
and two bonds. That gives it three modes of vibration: symmetric stretching, asymmetric stretching, and bending. More complicated molecules have even
fancier vibrational modes, like rocking, wagging, and twisting. If you know how many atoms a molecule has,
you can count its vibrational modes. Start with the total degrees of freedom, which is three times the number
of atoms in the molecule. That's because each atom can move
in three different directions. Three of the total correspond 
to translation when all the atoms 
are going in the same direction. And three, or two for linear molecules,
correspond to rotations. All the rest, 3N-6
or 3N-5 for linear molecules, are vibrations. So what's causing all this motion? Molecules move because they absorb
energy from their surroundings, mainly in the form of heat
or electromagnetic radiation. When this energy gets transferred
to the molecules, they vibrate, rotate, or translate faster. Faster motion increases the kinetic energy
of the molecules and atoms. We define this as an increase 
in temperature and thermal energy. This is the phenomenon your microwave oven
uses to heat your food. The oven emits microwave radiation,
which is absorbed by the molecules, especially those of water. They move around faster and faster, bumping into each other and increasing
the food's temperature and thermal energy. The greenhouse effect is another example. Some of the solar radiation 
that hits the Earth's surface is reflected back to the atmosphere. Greenhouse gases, like water vapor
and carbon dioxide absorb this radiation and speed up. These hotter, faster-moving molecules
emit infrared radiation in all directions, including back to Earth, warming it. Does all this molecular motion ever stop? You might think that would happen
at absolute zero, the coldest possible temperature. No one's ever managed to cool
anything down that much, but even if we could, molecules would still move due to
a quantum mechanical principle called zero-point energy. In other words, everything has been moving
since the universe's very first moments, and will keep going long, 
long after we're gone.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: A large protein consisting of 94 atoms has ____ vibrational ‘degrees of freedom.’
Options: A. 277, B. 276, C. 6, D. 282
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:

Question 2: What are the three basic ways molecules can move? Options: A. Rotation, translation, and vibration, B. Rotation, translation, and oscillation, C. Vibration, oscillation, and rotation, D. Translation, vibration, and reflection Correct Option: None
Question 3: What is the term used to describe the number of variables needed to understand the full system of a molecule's motion? Options: A. Degrees of freedom, B. Molecular motion, C. Kinetic energy, D. Thermal energy Correct Option: None

Question 6: What is the term used to describe the tiny change in distance between atoms in a molecule due to vibration? Options: A. Symmetric stretching, B. Asymmetric stretching, C. Bending, D. None of the above Correct Option: None
Question 7: How can you calculate the number of vibrational modes of a molecule? Options: A. 3N-6 (or 3N-5 for linear molecules), B. 3N-3 (or 3N-2 for linear molecules), C. 3N-2 (or 3N-1 for linear molecules), D. 3N-1 (or 3N for linear molecules) Correct Option: None
Question 8: What is the primary cause of the increase in temperature and thermal energy of a substance? Options: A. Absorption of energy from surroundings, B. Emission of energy to surroundings, C. Increase in kinetic energy, D. Decrease in kinetic energy Correct Option: None
Question 9: What is the phenomenon used by microwave ovens to heat food? Options: A. Conduction, B. Convection, C. Radiation, D. None of the above Correct Option: None
Question 10: Why do molecules continue to move even at absolute zero? Options: A. Due to residual heat energy, B. Due to external forces, C. Due to zero-point energy, D. Due to random chaotic movement Correct Option: None

Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:

Question 7: How can you calculate the number of vibrational modes of a molecule? Options: A. 3N-6 (or 3N-5 for linear molecules), B. 3N-3 (or 3N-2 for linear molecules), C. 3N-2 (or 3N-1 for linear molecules), D. 3N-1 (or 3N for linear molecules)

**Transcript**:
Harry Houdini was without doubt the most famous and talented Illusionist to ever walk the earth few performers have captured the Public's imagination like Houdini did and even today over a hundred years later his legacy continues to live on so here are five things you may not have known about this magnificent showman Houdini escapes from seemingly impossible situations thrilled audiences but his obsession for Perfection and extreme motivation in his prce practice often wasn't seen by his fans in order to perform his mind-blowing stuns Houdini had to train intensely both physically and mentally he trained himself to be ambidextrous making his left hand as able as his right he was said to practice untying knots with his toes so much so that his toes had the dexterity of his fingers he would swallow large objects and regurgitate them back up again he practiced slight of hand and misdirection in front of a large mirror for hours and hours at a time and his practice sessions were so constant that he would frequently forget to eat change and even bathe of course all this dedication consumed most of his time meaning there was hardly time to sleep 4 hours a night was said to be a lion for Houdini but if in his short hours of sleep he did awake with an idea for a new stun or trick there was always a notebook by his bedside in order for him to write it down he even had a large sunken bathtub installed in his house where he could practice his breath holds and would fill it with ice in order to prepare his body for his handcuffed free ing River plunges he built himself into the man he wanted to become and you can't help but respect every ounce of that his bizarre interest in the maab he would study murder cases and used to enjoy performing to inmates on death row he even bought a device that would eventually kill the men he was performing for a real electric chair which was used to kill inmates on death row at the Sing Sing prison he was also very interested in life after death he would visit hundreds of mediums and spiritual GTO togethers in an attempt to to contact his deceased mother who he loved dearly but of course he couldn't just turn up to a seance unnoticed so he would disguise himself with a hat and a fake beard Houdini later said that all mediums were conmen and wrote this in an article in the 25 years of my investigation and the hundreds of seances which I've attended I have never seen or heard anything that could convince me that there is a possibility of communications with the loved ones who have gone beyond despite saying this Houdini still believed in the afterlife he just wasn't convinced that communication was possible Houdini's imaginary son now it's unsure why Houdini and his wife of 32 years Bess didn't have children some say Bess was unable to carry and others say that Houdini was x-rayed many times by his brother who was remarkably New York's first x-ray specialist and the constant exposure to radiation made Houdini sterile but just because they couldn't have a child it didn't mean they couldn't invent one yep they invented a son and he was called mayor Samuel Houdini named after Harry's father while Harry was away he would write letters to Bess asking how his son was getting on and what he'd been up to Bess would let Harry know that mayor was doing well the final letters written about their son was that he was doing well and had now become the president of the United States now lots of people say that they were both just nuts but I see it as a cute way to bring each other closer together and help brighten the fact that he couldn't have children Houdini was killed by one of his own fans Harry died of peritonitis secondary to a ruptured appendix on October the 31st Halloween in 1926 he was aged just 52 his insurance company concluded that the death was due to him being punched in the stomach by a university student called Jay Gordon Whitehead Whitehead was witnessed delivering several heavy blows to Houdini's stomach before he had the chance to prepare after the incident Houdini continued performing his upcoming show in a great deal of pain the pain lasted for 2 days and when he finally visited a doctor he was told he had a fever and acute appendicitis he was advised to have immediate surgery but Houdini being so dedicated to his craft ignored the advice and decided to go on with another show when Houdini arrived at the Garrick theater in Detroit Michigan on October the 24th 1926 for what would be his last performance he had a fever of 104 and must have felt awful but despite this he took to the stage he was reported to have passed out during the show but was revived and continued to perform afterwards he was hospitalized at Detroit's Grace Hospital where he died shortly after his last words were said to be I am weaker I guess I have lost the fight the Houdini paranormal ritual despite Houdini not seeing any firsthand proof of communication with the afterlife he certainly believed in life after death and always told his wife B that if he died he would attempt to communicate with her if he was able to do so he gave her a secret code that if she heard being whispered one day or if a spiritualist said the secret code was coming through during a seance Bess would know it was her husband every Halloween Bess would haul a seance in an attempt to contact him but after 10 years with no success she gave up incredibly though the Seance still continues to this day every year on October the 31st a group of spiritualists hold a ritual in an attempt to communicate with Houdini unfortunately communication with him hasn't yet been successful so that's five little known facts about the most famous escape artist who has ever lived thanks for watching and catch you next week for another video

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Why did Houdini visit so many mediums?

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What was Harry Houdini's occupation? Options: A. Magician, B. Actor, C. Musician, D. Dancer Correct Option: None
Question 2: What was unique about Houdini's physical training? Options: A. He only trained his right hand, B. He was ambidextrous, C. He only trained his left hand, D. He didn't train physically Correct Option: None
Question 3: How many hours of sleep did Houdini typically get each night? Options: A. 8 hours, B. 6 hours, C. 4 hours, D. 2 hours Correct Option: None
Question 4: Why did Houdini visit hundreds of mediums and spiritual gatherings? Options: A. To learn new magic tricks, B. To contact his deceased mother, C. To prove that mediums were con artists, D. To become a medium himself Correct Option: None
Question 5: What was Houdini's conclusion about mediums after attending hundreds of seances? Options: A. They were all legitimate, B. Some were legitimate, while others were con artists, C. They were all con artists, D. He was unsure Correct Option: None
Question 6: Why did Houdini and his wife invent a son? Options: A. Because they wanted to adopt a child, B. Because they couldn't have children, C. Because they wanted to confuse their friends, D. Because they wanted to write a book about a fictional child Correct Option: None
Question 7: What was the name of Houdini's imaginary son? Options: A. Harry Jr., B. Mayor Samuel Houdini, C. Houdini Jr., D. Samuel Houdini Correct Option: None
Question 8: How did Houdini die? Options: A. From a heart attack, B. From peritonitis secondary to a ruptured appendix, C. From a stroke, D. From cancer Correct Option: None
Question 9: What was the secret code that Houdini gave to his wife Bess? Options: A. A specific word, B. A specific phrase, C. A specific number, D. Not specified in the transcript Correct Option: None
Question 10: What is still done every year on October 31st to try to communicate with Houdini? Options: A. A magic show, B. A seance, C. A memorial service, D. A party Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:

**Question 4: Why did Houdini visit hundreds of mediums and spiritual gatherings? Options: A. To learn new magic tricks, B. To contact his deceased mother, C. To prove that mediums were con artists, D. To become a medium himself**

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 12, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Harry Houdini was without doubt the most famous and talented Illusionist to ever walk the earth few performers have captured the Public's imagination like Houdini did and even today over a hundred years later his legacy continues to live on so here are five things you may not have known about this magnificent showman Houdini escapes from seemingly impossible situations thrilled audiences but his obsession for Perfection and extreme motivation in his prce practice often wasn't seen by his fans in order to perform his mind-blowing stuns Houdini had to train intensely both physically and mentally he trained himself to be ambidextrous making his left hand as able as his right he was said to practice untying knots with his toes so much so that his toes had the dexterity of his fingers he would swallow large objects and regurgitate them back up again he practiced slight of hand and misdirection in front of a large mirror for hours and hours at a time and his practice sessions were so constant that he would frequently forget to eat change and even bathe of course all this dedication consumed most of his time meaning there was hardly time to sleep 4 hours a night was said to be a lion for Houdini but if in his short hours of sleep he did awake with an idea for a new stun or trick there was always a notebook by his bedside in order for him to write it down he even had a large sunken bathtub installed in his house where he could practice his breath holds and would fill it with ice in order to prepare his body for his handcuffed free ing River plunges he built himself into the man he wanted to become and you can't help but respect every ounce of that his bizarre interest in the maab he would study murder cases and used to enjoy performing to inmates on death row he even bought a device that would eventually kill the men he was performing for a real electric chair which was used to kill inmates on death row at the Sing Sing prison he was also very interested in life after death he would visit hundreds of mediums and spiritual GTO togethers in an attempt to to contact his deceased mother who he loved dearly but of course he couldn't just turn up to a seance unnoticed so he would disguise himself with a hat and a fake beard Houdini later said that all mediums were conmen and wrote this in an article in the 25 years of my investigation and the hundreds of seances which I've attended I have never seen or heard anything that could convince me that there is a possibility of communications with the loved ones who have gone beyond despite saying this Houdini still believed in the afterlife he just wasn't convinced that communication was possible Houdini's imaginary son now it's unsure why Houdini and his wife of 32 years Bess didn't have children some say Bess was unable to carry and others say that Houdini was x-rayed many times by his brother who was remarkably New York's first x-ray specialist and the constant exposure to radiation made Houdini sterile but just because they couldn't have a child it didn't mean they couldn't invent one yep they invented a son and he was called mayor Samuel Houdini named after Harry's father while Harry was away he would write letters to Bess asking how his son was getting on and what he'd been up to Bess would let Harry know that mayor was doing well the final letters written about their son was that he was doing well and had now become the president of the United States now lots of people say that they were both just nuts but I see it as a cute way to bring each other closer together and help brighten the fact that he couldn't have children Houdini was killed by one of his own fans Harry died of peritonitis secondary to a ruptured appendix on October the 31st Halloween in 1926 he was aged just 52 his insurance company concluded that the death was due to him being punched in the stomach by a university student called Jay Gordon Whitehead Whitehead was witnessed delivering several heavy blows to Houdini's stomach before he had the chance to prepare after the incident Houdini continued performing his upcoming show in a great deal of pain the pain lasted for 2 days and when he finally visited a doctor he was told he had a fever and acute appendicitis he was advised to have immediate surgery but Houdini being so dedicated to his craft ignored the advice and decided to go on with another show when Houdini arrived at the Garrick theater in Detroit Michigan on October the 24th 1926 for what would be his last performance he had a fever of 104 and must have felt awful but despite this he took to the stage he was reported to have passed out during the show but was revived and continued to perform afterwards he was hospitalized at Detroit's Grace Hospital where he died shortly after his last words were said to be I am weaker I guess I have lost the fight the Houdini paranormal ritual despite Houdini not seeing any firsthand proof of communication with the afterlife he certainly believed in life after death and always told his wife B that if he died he would attempt to communicate with her if he was able to do so he gave her a secret code that if she heard being whispered one day or if a spiritualist said the secret code was coming through during a seance Bess would know it was her husband every Halloween Bess would haul a seance in an attempt to contact him but after 10 years with no success she gave up incredibly though the Seance still continues to this day every year on October the 31st a group of spiritualists hold a ritual in an attempt to communicate with Houdini unfortunately communication with him hasn't yet been successful so that's five little known facts about the most famous escape artist who has ever lived thanks for watching and catch you next week for another video

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Why did a punch most likely kill Houdini?
Options: A. because it broke his neck, B. because he was so weak, C. because he hadn't practiced the stunt enough, D. because he didn't seek appropriate medical attention until it was too late
Correct Option: D

mentally he trained himself to be ambidextrous making his left hand as able as his right he was said to practice untying knots with his toes so much so that his toes had the dexterity of his fingers he would swallow large objects and regurgitate them back up again he practiced slight of hand and misdirection in front of a large mirror for hours and hours at a time and his practice sessions were so constant that he would frequently forget to eat change and even bathe of course all this dedication consumed most of his time meaning there was hardly time to sleep 4 hours a night was said to be a Houdini still believed in the afterlife he just wasn't convinced that communication was possible Houdini's imaginary son now it's unsure why Houdini and his wife of 32 years Bess didn't have children Harry Houdini was without doubt the most famous and talented Illusionist to ever walk the earth few performers have captured the Public's imagination like Houdini did and even today over a hundred years later his legacy continues to live on so here are five things you may not have known about this magnificent showman Houdini escapes from seemingly impossible situations thrilled audiences but his obsession for Perfection and extreme motivation in his prce practice often wasn't seen by his fans in order to perform his mind-blowing stuns Houdini had to train intensely both physically and mentally he trained himself to be ambidextrous making his left hand as able as his right he was said to practice untying knots with his toes so much so that his toes had the dexterity of his fingers he would swallow large objects and regurgitate them back up again he practiced slight of hand and misdirection in front of a large mirror for hours and hours at a time and his practice sessions were so constant that he would frequently forget to eat change and even bathe of course all this dedication consumed most of his time meaning there was hardly time to sleep 4 hours a night was said to be a lion for Houdini but if in his short hours of sleep he did awake with an idea for a new stun or trick there was always a notebook by his bedside in order for him to write it down he even had a large sunken bathtub installed in his house where he could practice his breath holds and would fill it with ice in order to prepare his body for his handcuffed free ing River plunges he built himself into the man he wanted to become and you can't help but respect every ounce of that his bizarre interest in the maab he would study murder cases and used to enjoy performing to inmates on death row he even bought a device that would eventually kill the men he was performing for a real electric chair which was used to kill inmates on death row at the Sing Sing prison he was also very interested in life after death he would visit hundreds of mediums and spiritual GTO togethers in an attempt to to contact his deceased mother who he loved dearly but of course he couldn't just turn up to a seance unnoticed so he would disguise himself with a hat and a fake beard Houdini later said that all mediums were conmen and wrote this in an article in the 25 years of my investigation and the hundreds of seances which I've attended I have never seen or heard anything that could convince me that there is a possibility of communications with the loved ones who have gone beyond despite saying this Houdini still believed in the afterlife he just wasn't convinced that communication was possible Houdini's imaginary son now it's unsure why Houdini and his wife of 32 years Bess didn't have children heavy blows to Houdini's stomach before he had the chance to prepare after the incident Houdini continued performing his upcoming show in a great deal of pain the pain lasted for 2 days and when he
